This is a simple, silly little game that I picked up late friday night, just to play something while I watched some videos on my other monitor. I picked this game since its fast to download (300mb) , looked like a game that I could easily get into and the price is almost nothing.

The graphics are old-looking, but in my opinion kinda charming. The ak-47 looks like something taken out of the counter strike 1.6 era, but the game plays like a fast-paced, crazy FPS, serious sam/shadow warrior sort of game. The graphics was obviously made this was to be more of a humorous type of game.

The story doesn't make much sense and the voice-acting is pretty bad, but who cares. This is a game mostly focused on silly gameplay where you murder hordes of monsters and animals for a while. This game actually had more depth then I expected for the price, lots of characters to pick between, some sort of upgrade system, new unlockable levels, cheat mode enabled once you clear 30 waves, and so on.

I think the psysics are fun and satisfying in this game. Monster splatter to pieces when you shot them up with a shotgun, and I also tried out a revolver and what looked like a desert eagle pistol. There is some bugs and glitches here and there, but I got some laughs out of this little game anyway. Includes steam trading cards as well, so you can actually make your money back, or close to, by just selling the cards. Also achievements, stats and controller support for those that like that.

If you just want a little bit of fun alone or with friends ( yes, it has co-op) then by all means pick this up. Just don't expect to much in terms of graphics or story. Blood and bacon does have 100+ levels though, so gameplay-wise it actually have a lot of content for the asking price.

reviewText:
The Xbox Live Indie Market was quite possibly the closest thing console gamers could get to the boundless lunacy offered by some of the lower end Steam games or alpha swamps like Gamejolt or itch.io. Blood and Bacon showed up on there in 2013 and although there are no noticeable changes in its jump to PC, this isn't really the kind of game you'll need an HD remaster to enjoy/despise.

Make no mistake, Blood and Bacon is a shoddy game; the giant zombified pigs that you must spend each in-game day murdering range from acting suspiciously disinterested at you shooting them in the face to balls-out enraged, charging through solid surfaces and straight over the tops of buildings to crush you. It's an ugly, glitchy mess but it is also deeply entrenched enough in its madness to work.

Instructions are given to you by a farmer in a pitchless monotone, pinned to the barn wall by his own pitchfork, his eyes bulging and manic. You grow to look forward to Revenge Day, a weekly celebration of your survival where all of your guns are loaded up with explosive ammo and firing an AK-47 into a rampage of swine looks like a half ton of fireworks going off in a medical waste bin. Enormous pigs drop by once every ten days for an epic boss battle. There's a last stand mode.

I don't think I ever finished it the first time around; over a hundred levels of this madness is more than my delicate psychological balance can take quite frankly but you should easily grind some enjoyment out of it for the meagre asking price.

Firstly getting into start screen. The start screen is very basic, but it's very well done. It's easy to find the graphic settings, the controls, the co-op, and single player buttons, not to mention the audio itself.

Getting into the actual gameplay, It's amazing. Although the farmer is very annoying, but for what you pay for the game it is really good. The guns are really good, and powerful at low rounds, and as you progress it gets harder to kill the boars. Getting into the days, I think 101 days is a little bit long to play, but if you have the time it's fun, and the characters themselves are great to play as.

The bosses get harder every 10 days which is really challenging and fun. I love the aspect that they can heal so that they don't die so easily, and you have to actually do a lot of hard work to kill them, but the best part of the bosses is the names for the fat pig that's in the middle.

Getting on to the grinder. The grinder is amazing, but it is used for powerups which is also a great addition to the game, and make sit much better to play for something else other than just killing boars that are on steroids, but apart from that stuff that's all there is to the grinder.

Getting on the farmer himself. He is funny, but also annoying. His jokes aren't that great, and could be worked on a little bit, but apart from that the farmer is a great guy. Especially when you shoot him, and he starts getting mad, and eventually throws stuff at you.

Getting on the boars. There is a mix of boar's from small to large, and from skeletons, to bosses, and from boar's to pigs. The game on a whole is amazing, and I love it.

Getting on to the price. The price of the game should be more, because of how fun the game is especially when you play with friends, and have a laugh with them. So I recommend the price should be set atleast at ¬£2.50, and not 0.75. I'm not complaining about it being so cheap, but I think it should be more.

On a whole I would recommend anyone to get this game that enjoys shooter genres, and loves to play co-op with friends.

reviewText:
I admit. When I looked at the screenshots and an 'overwhelmingly positive' rating of this game, I thought it was one of those where people give it a 'thumbs up' because it's so bad it's either good or everyone is making a joke about it.

But not Blood and Bacon. It looks poor (on screenshots) and it's not a graphical marvel in the game, nor does it have amazing music or sound effects. But when you pair up with a friend, it's an absolute blast.

The main objective is to kill and destroy evil pig demon creature things, whatever they are. Protecting the farm is paramount as is your own life. Remember how I said the graphics aren't state of the art? While that is true and everything is a bit more basic (think Half-Life 1 era), the dismemberment and blood effects on the pigs are surprisingly good looking and fun. In fact, sometimes taking off a pig's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• or head will expose its spine for you to shoot at and do extra damage.

As you finish each level (or day), you will sometimes get new weapons in the barn, which acts as your base (and houses the eternally-impaled farmer which gives you advice and spurs you on). There's no buying or upgrading per se, but you can get the farm's bizarre grinder to start up by feeding it chunks of dead pigs, then use its charged up state to manufacture more ammunition, grenades, milk (health packs) and so on.

Every now and then, you will have a night defence, which brings out the more nasty kinds of the creatures. I'm not going to spoil it for you but it's fun. There's also bosses which will taunt you, munch at you and kick you. They're bullet sponges but that's okay because they're a lot of fun to fight. Playing with a friend will allow one to try and get its attention while the other one runs over to one of the water pumps to heal up (albeit slowly).

You're tasked with clearing a farm where boars and other livestock have gone crazy and grown quite resilient (possibly undead): your only company in all this is the farm owner who seems to be quite happy with being stuck on a wall with a pitchfork in its chest.
What follows is a basic but enjoyable wave shooter where you must survive for 101 days against porcine foes and bosses, either alone or in co-op: the actual gameplay is quite barebones but fun enough especially in short bursts.

PROS:

-the silly premise works well and is quite funny

-the over the top gore and amount of gibs can get quite hilarious, same goes for the game's brand of humour (which goes from childish to toilet)

-there's at least some attempts at providing variety thanks to a few different enemy models/ types

-provides a fair to intense challenge depending on difficulty level and/ or whether you're alone or in co-op

-the short day duration, with most being complete in a couple minutes, makes it perfect for a quick play

-if you can stomach the basic, unvaried gameplay there's quite alot to play through as the 101 days'll take at least 5 hours to complete

CONS:

-the low production values are evident in the simple graphics and sounds

-gets repetitive pretty fast due to the lack of variety and single game area

-a few difficulty spikes

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=652505338

Blood and Bacon is pretty polarizing when it comes to enjoying it as you'll either appreciate its simple, gory, shoot-a-ton-o-stuff mindset or dislike it for its basicness, repetitiveness and toiler humor. There's really no way around it as you'll be doing mostly the same thing for most waves (that is, shooting purcines until they die/ gib/ explode while trying not to be gored to death): some variety can come from armored enemies that you must shoot in the back or bosses that require a bit of strategy but that's all.Said repetitiveness is also made stronger by the overall lack of different enemy models and the fact you'll be seeing the same two bosses types over and over every ten days with- at most- only slight changes in how they work.

As for what it does right well, the game is extremely easy to pick up and play and the fact each day is so short means you can give it a quick go even if you have little time. The toilet humor can be funny at times- if you're ok with that brand of humor ofc- and the huge amount of gibs/ blood on screen is as amusing as it is satisfying to see after you've managed to clear a particularly hard day. While basic the gameplay can also be quite challenging especially when playing solo as certain enemies can kill you in a few hits if you let them get too close: same goes for bosses as they'll require a good amount of concentration to succeed.

For me Blood and Bacon was a fun yet slightly dull and somewhat forgettable experience, an one trick pony if you wish: but for a dollar I feel I got enough enjoyment from it to justify its purchase hence my thumbs up. As for you well, it's quite decent if you're looking for something silly to play in short bursts, even more so with a friend.

reviewText:
Blood and Bacon is an arena shooter where you run around a completely absurd farm to rid it from evil pigs that have taken over it.

The premise is simple: You grab your favorite pistol and main gun, shoot all the evil pigs and come back to the barn to pass the day. There is also a meat grinding mechanic where you can exchange the bits of the dead pigs for bonuses like ammo for your main gun, grenades and a couple of other powerups.

While the gameplay itself is sadly not much remarkable, the absurdist elements and humor of the game is what really sets it apart, and it's what's going to really carry to game or not for you.

One other major flaw of the game is that it really overstays its welcome in the ending levels. If you make it to day 20 and you either start to get bored or weren't hooked to it yet, you'll be justified in leaving.

Overall, it's a quirky game that's very wekk worth its admission price if you are looking for an arena shooter.

I picked it up for 99 cents before the deal started; I have to say I still feel I got my money's worth, and more! I thought that was good,  so 74 cents is a real steal. GET IT NOW!  :) The devs are adding new content every week, and they listen to the players; which is too often a rarity nowadays.

If you're a fan of Jim Sterling, you'll love this game since he voices the farmer stuck to the wall by a pitchfork. There's a variety of crazy characters to choose from; the roster is going up with them, as well as weapons, and craftable powerups. Power ups can be made by using A Machine For Pigs (meat grinder) if you'll pardon the bad pun; you make stuff by kicking pig parts into it.

This is also a survival game if you haven't guessed; it is a welcome twist on the genre to add humor. The most you could be terrified is when facing either the hordes of undead pigs, or bosses in the dark, with a flashlight. It's all good fun, but messy. :)

Plus, it's possible to reload while running, and they just recently added fov settings among other things.

Overall, I greatly enjoyed it, but if you have a problem with the porcine slaughter of thousands not so innocent pigs then this is not the game for you.

reviewText: Blood and Bacon is a gory and fantastically enjoyable and relaxing experience in which you will gun down thousands upon thousands of pigs on a farm over 101 levels. Overtime, you will unlock several unique weapons and acquire comical powerups from a functional pig grinder on the farm. Although it seems straightforward at first, the variety in the games levels will always be a challenge; just as you set into a rhythm, the game throws several new enemy types upon you, forcing you to stay on your toes. The pig types include armored pigs, super fast pigs, tiny pigs, huge pigs, skeletal pigs, princess pigs, pigs that run in herds, pigs that can grow in size, and many other types that can be tricky to deal with when first encountered. Each of the game's weapons, from an uzi to a missile launcher, feel powerful and satisfying to play with. At its low price, there are very very few games on any platform that can match Blood and Bacon in value, fun, and comedy. I have gotten more entertainment out of this game than games that cost 60 times its value, and I highly recommend it as a casual shooter to play through.

reviewText:
Product received for free

This game is pretty much Left 4 Dead but replace the zombies with Pigs. Graphics are look dated but are passable if you are someone that doesn't care about the way the game looks. Anyone that has Played old Valve games (such as Counter Strike Left 4 Dead 1 or Half Life 1) will somewhat feel right at home. This game looks like the Dollar it is worth. The shooting is really good but nothing really new. Guns are somewhat transparent but I am pretty sure the guys wanted it to look that way.

The few bad things about this game are that the Electrical fence is pretty much useless. The Meat Grinder is a way for you to get Ammo, Grenades, exc. The way to go about this is to kill most of the pigs near the machiene and shoot some of the chunks of meat into the Grinder to get the Machiene started and most of the chunks will start to flow in and the more chunks go in the more rewards you are able to get. But Their is no way you will be able to collect while their are still enemies alive becauset they Knock you all around to where you can barily shoot with acuracy. The times it is Nighttime is really not all that different to the Daytime only black sky and the colors are dimmed down a little.

reviewText:
After completing the game I knew I just had to come back and edit my review. Don't worry this updated review is going the be spoiler free.

I got this game after seeing not only the video, the price, but also the number of positive reviews.
After playing it for a short time I became hooked. I just had to play this game to the end and I did. Blood and Bacon is an addictive and fun arena style wave shooter. You play as a hired gun with one job at hand to rid the farm of an army of undead hogs.  As you progress new weapons and items unlock, and at the same time enemies get bigger, stronger, and grow in number. After so many days you will encounter a boss battle. Each boss battle becomes more intense and challenging making victory feel more rewarding. With the number of options from all the unlockables players are able to come up with various combinations of how to handle each day.

As for story it stays very simple and instead focuses more on the gameplay. That isn't a bad thing if you are a fan of games like Doom, or Serious Sam. The music is very catchy and really gets you in the mood to play. The graphics are closer to classic shooter style from the N64/PS2 era that just fits the theme of the game so well. In honestly it's more of a breath of fresh air compared to other modern games. The game has an art style that I haven't seen since Conker's Bad Fur Day. In all honestly it's just another reason why I enjoy this game so much.

After all that said I still highly recommend this game. It's not only addictive but also a great time killer. So if you have the shekels to spare please pick it up. You can't go wrong with this one.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a game to play for a couple of hours just to kill time and have a bit a fun, this game might be for you. If you're looking for a cheap game with massive replay value, turn back.

At the start of the game you'll find yourself having a lot of fun and looking foward to new weapons and wondering what those things on the wall are; however, by the end of the game you'll be wanting use those guns to shoot your eyes out. Around level 45 or so, the game has no incentive to play left. You'll have unlocked all of the weapons, and more importantly, the farmer will have run out of class A puns to entertain your soul.

So why keep playing? The final achievement requires you wage through 100 levels of (by that time) terrible gameplay and lackluster mechanics. My 8.5 hours do not represent multiple playthoughs, but merely one. There is one final incentive, being the boss fight (quite a challange if you haven't started cheating), and some new dialogue from our old friend monotonous man (a. k. a. the farmer). So at least your weakened heart can look forward to that.

Have fun fighting your way through Buckingham Palace. (Credits for the pun gold goes to my pal whom I wasted 8.5 hours with.)

reviewText:
Such a fun game. I played a ton of this back when it was on Xbox 360, and I plan to put a lot more time into it now that it's on PC. It's an extremely cheesy, ridiculous, disgustingly bloody game where you run around shooting pigs, kicking their body parts into a grinder to buy ammo/grenades/milk/melee boosters/etc, and talk to a farmer with a close relationship with a pitchfork.

It starts off slow, but once you hit the Princess Blubbergut boss fight it all starts to get much, much more bloody and crazy. Early on you're only dealing with 10-20 pigs in a day, but after a while it'll crank up the difficulty with 50+ pigs at a time. Revenge Days are the best days of the week, giving you infinite explosive ammo and tons of pigs to gib for the grinder.

There's a decent amount of weapons, 100 days (levels), and three characters to unlock. There's a lot of content here for $1! I'd highly recommend it if you enjoy horde-style games, ridiculous gore, and a game that doesn't take itself seriously.

The only issues I've had with the game are not being able to rebind keys*, not able to edit the camera while using a keyboard (but you can with a controller by pressing Start), the black border around the screen no matter the resolution you use, some sound issues with gunshots, and sadly that co-op (which was on the Xbox 360 version) is not in this current PC port. However, the developer has said he's interested in doing it, but it sounds like it'll only be possible if the game sells well enough.

The rest of the issues I'm sure will be fixed sooner or later. The default keybindings are fine (minus X being use, instead of E), but I'd still like to be able to rebind*.

Also, the developer is extremely cool. If you have any issues, just hit him up, he responds really quickly and will try to help you fix any problems! I hope he'll bring some of his other games to Steam one day soon, I'd kill a thousand skeleton pigs just to play DeadKings (with the multiplayer included, hopefully!) on PC.

*Edit: Rebinding has now been added in the most recent patch. You just have to go to your game folder, find the KEYBOARD folder, then edit the KEYS_BU.txt to your liking. Once you're done rename that file to KEYS.txt and it'll work just fine!

reviewText:
Such a fun game. I played a ton of this back when it was on Xbox 360, and I plan to put a lot more time into it now that it's on PC. It's an extremely cheesy, ridiculous, disgustingly bloody game where you run around shooting pigs, kicking their body parts into a grinder to buy ammo/grenades/milk/melee boosters/etc, and talk to a farmer with a close relationship with a pitchfork.

It starts off slow, but once you hit the Princess Blubbergut boss fight it all starts to get much, much more bloody and crazy. Early on you're only dealing with 10-20 pigs in a day, but after a while it'll crank up the difficulty with 50+ pigs at a time. Revenge Days are the best days of the week, giving you infinite explosive ammo and tons of pigs to gib for the grinder.

There's a decent amount of weapons, 100 days (levels), and three characters to unlock. There's a lot of content here for $1! I'd highly recommend it if you enjoy horde-style games, ridiculous gore, and a game that doesn't take itself seriously.

The only issues I've had with the game are not being able to rebind keys*, not able to edit the camera while using a keyboard (but you can with a controller by pressing Start), the black border around the screen no matter the resolution you use, some sound issues with gunshots, and sadly that co-op (which was on the Xbox 360 version) is not in this current PC port. However, the developer has said he's interested in doing it, but it sounds like it'll only be possible if the game sells well enough.

The rest of the issues I'm sure will be fixed sooner or later. The default keybindings are fine (minus X being use, instead of E), but I'd still like to be able to rebind*.

reviewText:
I don't even know what I just played.

Blood and Bacon is a wave survival game on a farm where you fight lots, and lots, and lots of pig-type species.

Obviously this is an indie game and not very full featured, but I paid about $.90 for it so whatever.

The graphics feel ancient, like N64 era, but it's not that big of a deal. The sound design isn't anything out of the ordinary but is satisfying, especially when you use the rocket launcher. Most of the guns have incomplete or basically non existent reload animations, and you can reload constantly even when your magazine is full.  The voice acting for the farmer is completely awful, maybe on purpose, but the voice acting for bosses and the sounds made by the pigs and grinder are spot on. There is some occasional humor to the game, most of it coming from the Farmer's lines, the bosses and hidden messages sprawled about the farm, but the game itself is pretty funny considering you are basically murdering a ton of hogs and pigs and undead pigs.

In many ways this game is like survival mode in L4D, just very barebones. Each pig you kill, you can push it's gibs or entire body into a grinder that magically turns them in to resources so you can buy grenades, revive pills, milk, ammo, nukes, and superstrength.

The only negative thing I have to say about the actual gameplay is that survival mode takes a long time. 100 days. If you are actually pushing everything in to the grinder, it takes quite a while to get through each day. Every 10 days my co op partner and I would be like 30 days and it's not over? Maybe 50 because we have like 2 guns left to unlock? Maybe 75? It's 100!?"  All in all though
recommended: it's worth 90 cents for a few hours of fun until you get tired of it. I don't know what the original price of the game was but I'd still pay a few dollars more for it."
